Award.AwardTitle: Friction Stir Blind Riveting for Dissimilar Materials

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports fundamental research on a novel one-sided joining process of dissimilar materials through friction stir blind riveting. The research objective is to establish the link among the thermomechanical inputs, material properties, microstructural characteristics, and resulting joint strength. Specifically, the research will formulate a physics-based thermo-mechanical model for intrinsic forces and torques with frictionally rotated rivet and validate the model experimentally; test the hypothesis that viscoplastic type material response can simulate metal deformation in friction stir blind riveting; investigate the effects of process conditions on material flow, defect formation, and joint strength; analyze microstructure evolution and its impacts on joint failure mechanisms; identify different thermomechanically affected zones; and assess the friction stir mechanisms for different joining materials.

Research results will provide knowledge and understanding to meet the critical need for the incorporation of advanced lightweight materials in the automotive industry. The capability to incorporate these lightweight materials in an automobile is crucial for improving fuel economy and reducing environmental impact. This technology combines the benefits of friction stir welding with the strength of blind rivets. The research will advance this new joining technique for a wide range of dissimilar materials, from metals to composites. Research findings will also have a broad impact on other transportation industries, such as aerospace, rail, and shipbuilding, where joining materials with different weights or functionalities is increasingly demanded but limited by traditional joining techniques. This project will promote active learning for industrial practitioners, and broaden participation of underrepresented student groups. The research outcomes will be integrated into undergraduate/graduate course development, and hands-on modules for K12 education.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigates a single-sided friction stir blind riveting (viz. FSBR) process of dissimilar materials. FSBR combines the strength of both friction stir processing and mechanical blind riveting with a reduced penetration force and enables a strong joint of two or multiple different materials for weight reduction or tailored properties. This research has been demonstrated the technical feasibility of joining aluminum, magnesium, and short-carbon-fiber-reinforced thermoplastic composites with the FSBR process. More specifically, this project has six accomplishments. First, the process physics is investigated through analytical modeling and a combined finite element and mesh-free method, which explains the formation of mechanical interlocking, demonstrates the importance of material stacking sequence and identifies the key factor in the energy consumption.  Second, it is demonstrated that the frictional effect can enhance the joint strength owing to the formation of mechanical interlocking and metallurgical bonding. Third, the atmospheric corrosion behavior of FSBR lap joints is investigated, where crevice corrosion can cause aluminum workpiece corroded even coupled with a more active material, e.g. magnesium. Fourth, the as-fabricated and corroded FSBR joints are compared for their mechanical properties. It is found that the rivet between the two work materials is barely corroded because their gap is only in nano-scale, minimizes the exposure of rivet to a corrosive environment, and maintains the majority of the joint strength although the work materials corroded or degraded. Fifth, it has been proved the feasibility of combining micro X-ray computed tomography and volumetric digital image correlation in conjunction with mechanical testing to probe three-dimensional deformation behavior in dense fiber reinforced polymer composite, where unique deformation mechanisms such as internal shear and microstructure-dependent local buckling can be observed in situ. And, finally, different affected zones and their local mechanical properties are identified for both aluminum and carbon fiber composite. This research can potentially benefit the societies, such as the design of friction stir riveting, corrosion protection for dissimilar material joints and experimental mechanics. This project has supported two Ph.D. and three undergraduate students during their study. The research results have been integrated into both undergraduate (e.g. Manufacturing Processes) and graduate courses (e.g. Weld Design and Performance), presented to middle school students and teachers through the outreach activities (e.g. Hawaii P-20 program), and disseminated to peer-reviewed journals and conferences.


Last Modified: 03/31/2018
Modified by: Jingjing Li
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This project investigates a single-sided friction stir blind riveting (viz. FSBR) process of dissimilar materials. FSBR combines the strength of both friction stir processing and mechanical blind riveting with a reduced penetration force and enables a strong joint of two or multiple different materials for weight reduction or tailored properties. This research has been demonstrated the technical feasibility of joining aluminum, magnesium, and short-carbon-fiber-reinforced thermoplastic composites with the FSBR process. More specifically, this project has six accomplishments. First, the process physics is investigated through analytical modeling and a combined finite element and mesh-free method, which explains the formation of mechanical interlocking, demonstrates the importance of material stacking sequence and identifies the key factor in the energy consumption. Second, it is demonstrated that the frictional effect can enhance the joint strength owing to the formation of mechanical interlocking and metallurgical bonding. Third, the atmospheric corrosion behavior of FSBR lap joints is investigated, where crevice corrosion can cause aluminum workpiece corroded even coupled with a more active material, e.g. magnesium. Fourth, the as-fabricated and corroded FSBR joints are compared for their mechanical properties. It is found that the rivet between the two work materials is barely corroded because their gap is only in nano-scale, minimizes the exposure of rivet to a corrosive environment, and maintains the majority of the joint strength although the work materials corroded or degraded. Fifth, it has been proved the feasibility of combining micro X-ray computed tomography and volumetric digital image correlation in conjunction with mechanical testing to probe three-dimensional deformation behavior in dense fiber reinforced polymer composite, where unique deformation mechanisms such as internal shear and microstructure-dependent local buckling can be observed in situ. And, finally, different affected zones and their local mechanical properties are identified for both aluminum and carbon fiber composite. This research can potentially benefit the societies, such as the design of friction stir riveting, corrosion protection for dissimilar material joints and experimental mechanics. This project has supported two Ph.D. and three undergraduate students during their study. The research results have been integrated into both undergraduate (e.g. Manufacturing Processes) and graduate courses (e.g. Weld Design and Performance), presented to middle school students and teachers through the outreach activities (e.g. Hawaii P-20 program), and disseminated to peer-reviewed journals and conferences.
